title: 106_hr583
content: The Act may be cited as the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" and addresses the treatment of Assistant United States Attorneys. The "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" amends the Civil Service Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys in the definition of a law enforcement officer. The Act amends the definition of an Assistant United States Attorney under title 5, United States Code, and includes them in the Federal Employees' Retirement System as law enforcement officers. The Act amends the definition of an Assistant United States Attorney under title 5, United States Code, including them in the Federal Employees' Retirement System as law enforcement officers. The Act amends the definition of an Assistant United States Attorney under title 5, United States Code, by adding an Assistant United States Attorney as a law enforcement officer in the Federal Employees' Retirement System. The Act amends the definition of an Assistant United States Attorney by including them as law enforcement officers in the Federal Employees' Retirement System. The effective date for this Act and its amendments is the first day of the first applicable pay period after a 90-day period from the date of enactment. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. For the purposes of this section, an incumbent is an individual appointed as an Assistant United States Attorney before the effective date of this Act and serving in that capacity on such date. The Department of Justice must provide notice to incumbents regarding their election rights under this Act within 6 months of its effective date. Incumbents have the option to make an election under this Act. The Department of Justice must notify incumbents of their election rights under this Act. Incumbents can choose to be treated according to the Act's amendments or as if the Act never existed. Failure to elect on time is considered an election under the Act. Failure to timely elect under this subsection will be treated as an election under the Act. The deadline for making an election is within 90 days of receiving notice or the incumbent's separation. An election under this subsection must be made before the 90th day after receiving notice or the incumbent's separation to be effective. No changes in retirement coverage will occur until the election is made. Interim status provision ensures no change in retirement coverage for incumbents until an election is made under the Act. Retroactive effect applies to service performed after the election date. The retroactive effect of the election under the Act applies to all service performed by an incumbent as an Assistant United States Attorney, both before and after the effective date of the election. The Act ensures that the election for Assistant United States Attorneys is retroactive and subject to applicable provisions of title 5, United States Code. The Department of Justice is required to make makeup contributions under subchapter III of chapter 83 or chapter 84 of title 5. The Act mandates makeup contributions by the Department of Justice to the Office of Personnel Management for the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The Office of Personnel Management requires remittance of additional contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund, which are to be deposited in the Treasury of the United States. The total amount to be remitted includes individual and Government contributions for all incumbents described in the subsection. The Office of Personnel Management mandates remittance of additional contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund, including individual and Government contributions for all incumbents. No individual liability is imposed by this Act. The Office of Personnel Management requires additional contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund for all incumbents. No individual liability is created for any contribution shortfall. Regulations will be established by the Office of Personnel Management. The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations, including determining interest on contributions. The term "Assistant United States Attorney" is defined as an assistant appointed under title 28, United States Code.
